{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3232880,"name":"Huuble","username":"Huuble","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/cc9497/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-09-17T23:56:56.155Z","cooked":"

I just start using team 364 BaseFalconSwerve to run our drivetrain. And I wonder how to know Max Velocity and Max Acceleration of our robot?
After trying, I discovered that Max Acceleration is related to robot rotation. But I don’t know why.
Can anyone explain that, please?

It might be for acceleration limiting, which would be affected by your center of mass and whatever wheelbase width you have
This is a good post explaining that. (Second half of the post)

FRC 95 The Grasshoppers 2023 Build Thread Open Alliance
Me too! It bears a strong resemblance to our 2015 arm, but will be much faster. The composite construction is totally new to us as an FRC team, hopefully we didn’t bite off too much. Thanks! Drills depend on the game, naturally, but a few types of drills get used over and over. Unobstructed cycles to HP station Unobstructed cycles to randomly distributed game pieces on the ground Cycles with random obstructions placed in the way (old robots, trash cans, whatever) Cycles against an active d…

However, I could be completely wrong and it’s asking about motor power.

It is a little hard for me, because it is beyond my academic level. Is there an easy way for me to calculate? For example, I have seen a sheet for robot PID constants.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-09-18T00:42:02.742Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":252,"readers_count":251,"score":70.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":441105,"topic_slug":"how-to-know-max-velocity-and-max-acceleration-of-our-robot","display_username":"Huuble","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":52966,"username":"Eliot","name":"Eliot Dunn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eliot/{size}/207280_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60507,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-know-max-velocity-and-max-acceleration-of-our-robot/441105/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3232896,"name":"Eliot Dunn","username":"Eliot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eliot/{size}/207280_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-18T00:47:05.199Z","cooked":"

I mean, you could just guess. I assume your max acceleration is going to be around 1g, or ~10 m/s^2
If your robot’s center of gravity is too high, it will tip under that acceleration. So, a very very conservative limit would be around 5 m/s^2. I’m sure almost every robot can accelerate faster than that, though. We just want to make sure that we accelerate slow enough so we don’t tip.
I assume max velocity is just the fastest speed that the code will let you go, so you could leave that uncapped or at 16 ft/s for a pretty normal speed.

You’ll have to convert those units to whatever the code wants, though.

I see.
However, I still have a question, what is the real max number of those constants? I think I will modify it from big to small so that our robot can run as fast as possible.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-09-18T00:58:21.078Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":230,"readers_count":229,"score":81.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":441105,"topic_slug":"how-to-know-max-velocity-and-max-acceleration-of-our-robot","display_username":"Huuble","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":52966,"username":"Eliot","name":"Eliot Dunn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eliot/{size}/207280_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60507,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-know-max-velocity-and-max-acceleration-of-our-robot/441105/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3232899,"name":"Eliot Dunn","username":"Eliot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eliot/{size}/207280_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-18T01:03:20.697Z","cooked":"

For acceleration, assuming that you won’t be able to tip at all, it depends, on a lot of things. If it’s a full size robot, I wouldn’t expect more possible acceleration than ~9.6 m/s^2, because you are probably using treaded wheels and their coefficient of friction would get you around there. Motor power is also something that would effect that, maybe bring it down to ~9.4 m/s^2, depending on current limits, you robot weight, and what motors you are using.

With your gearing, NEOs have a theroretical max speed of 14.5 ft/s while falcons have a theroretical max speed of 16.3 ft/s. Neither of those speeds will ever be reached with that gearing, because of resistance in the geartrain and limited acceleration space

There’s a low tech way of getting a tape measure and marking out every foot as hash marks. Then record your robot going full speed and see how many ft/s it is.

Is that mean I need to set a number bigger than it can actually run when testing?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2023-09-18T01:16:25.357Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":171,"readers_count":170,"score":39.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":441105,"topic_slug":"how-to-know-max-velocity-and-max-acceleration-of-our-robot","display_username":"Huuble","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":33848,"username":"jedgar6","name":"jedgar6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jedgar6/{size}/200602_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60507,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-know-max-velocity-and-max-acceleration-of-our-robot/441105/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3232908,"name":"jedgar6","username":"jedgar6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jedgar6/{size}/200602_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-18T02:05:53.186Z","cooked":"

I am not exactly sure what you are asking? The above answers are based on theoretical (which will get you very close) ways to know your max velocity. If you are looking for your practical (physical) speed the way I would do it would be current limit your drivetrain in code and remove any acceleration curves on your controls. Then set up the markers on the carpet and then go from standing still to max speed. However, at 14 ft/s you are going to need a lot of room. I’m not exactly sure how useful or practical doing this is but science is science.

jedgar6:

remove any acceleration curves on your controls.

I understand your method now, and I will try it. Thank you!
